user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of read_cb:
```c
static ssize_t
read_cb (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *mem, size_t size)
{
  struct Holder *holder = cls;
  void *src;
  void *buf;
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t offset;
  size_t r_size;

  if (pos > SSIZE_MAX)
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  offset = (size_t) pos;
  src = malloc (size);
  if (NULL == src)
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  r_size = fread (src, 1, size, holder->file);
  if (0 == r_size)
  {
    ret = (0 != ferror (holder->file)) ?
          MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR : MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM;
    goto done;
  }
  if (MHD_YES != compress_buf (&holder->stream, src, r_size, &offset, &buf,
                               &size, holder->buf))
    ret = MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  else
  {
    memcpy (mem, buf, size);
    ret = (ssize_t) size;
  }
  free (buf); /* Buf may be set even on error return. */
done:
  free (src);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: free (buf); /* Buf may be set even on error return. */
explanation: Only the listed fragments need further investigation with respect to MISRA C:2023 Rule 21.17 because they directly affect the parameters and buffers involved in the single use of a <string.h> function in this routine. The remaining code fragments are not relevant to this rule: declarations and simple assignments do not invoke string-handling functions; the check for pos against SSIZE_MAX and the cast to size_t prevent an invalid conversion of the pos parameter; the NULL check after allocation and the early-return on zero read prevent proceeding with invalid inputs; the final free(src) and return logic are standard resource-management and control-flow constructs. No other calls to <string.h> functions appear in the function, so there are no additional locations that need to be examined for accesses beyond object bounds under Rule 21.17.
